data.title: Analysis of Land Use Gravity Center Change and Carbon Emission Impact in Chengdu Plain of China from 2006 to 2022
data.meta_description: As the economic center and major grain-producing area in Southwest China, the calculation of the carbon budget and the protection of cultivated land in the Chengdu Plain are of vital significance for China to achieve a carbon peak strategy and ensure food security. For the purpose of clarifying the trend of land use focus and carbon emissions in the Chengdu Plain, the carbon peak level of land use in 33 counties in the Chengdu Plain was explored. Based on the gravity center model and IPCC carbon emission coefficient method, the changing trend of land use gravity center and carbon emission in Chengdu Plain from 2006 to 2022 was clarified. PLS regression model and LMDI model were used to explore the main influencing factors of the carbon emission of cropland and the carbon emission of building land. PLUS model was used to simulate future land use patterns and carbon emissions. (1) The center of gravity of cropland, building land, water, and other and unused land shifted to the northeast by 4.23 km, 5.46 km, 8.44 km, and 31.58 km, respectively, and that of forest and grass shifted to the southeast by 11.12 km and 3.41 km, respectively. For major food crops, the centers of gravity of rice and maize moved northeastward by 15.47 km and 7.52 km, respectively, while wheat moved southwestward by 17.77 km. (2) From 2006 to 2022, carbon emissions from land use in the 33 counties of the Chengdu Plain are all on the rise, with a total increase of 13.552 million tons, and carbon sinks in the 31 counties continue to decline, with a total decrease of 0.691 million tons. (3) Under the natural scenario, carbon sink scenario, and carbon reduction scenario, the carbon emissions from land use decrease by 0.5391 million tons, 3.4728 million tons, and 4.5265 million tons from 2022, respectively. Among the 33 counties in the Chengdu Plain, 11 counties did not achieve carbon peak under the natural scenario, 5 counties did not achieve carbon peak under the carbon sink scenario, and all the counties achieved carbon peak under the carbon sink scenario. During the study period, there was a serious loss of cropland in the Chengdu Plain, mainly to building land in the central part of the Chengdu Plain and to forests within the Longmen Mountain, Longquan Mountain, and Leshan City, and there is a need to strengthen cropland protection in this region in the future. Under the natural scenario, carbon sink scenario, and carbon reduction scenario, land use in the Chengdu Plain region can achieve carbon peak, and the carbon reduction model will be more helpful for the counties to achieve carbon peak.

Abstract

:

As the economic center and major grain-producing area in Southwest China, the calculation of the carbon budget and the protection of cultivated land in the Chengdu Plain are of vital significance for China to achieve a carbon peak strategy and ensure food security. For major food crops, the centers of gravity of rice and maize moved northeastward by 15.47 km and 7.52 km, respectively, while wheat moved southwestward by 17.77 km. (2) From 2006 to 2022, carbon emissions from land use in the 33 counties of the Chengdu Plain are all on the rise, with a total increase of 13.552 million tons, and carbon sinks in the 31 counties continue to decline, with a total decrease of 0.691 million tons. (3) Under the natural scenario, carbon sink scenario, and carbon reduction scenario, the carbon emissions from land use decrease by 0.5391 million tons, 3.4728 million tons, and 4.5265 million tons from 2022, respectively. 1. Introduction

China’s Chengdu Plain, as the economic center of Southwest China, has serious energy consumption and carbon reduction pressures, and urgently needs to accelerate the pace of low-carbon development. The Chengdu Plain is an essential major grain-producing area in China, which serves as a linchpin in safeguarding the nation’s food security. In June 2022, when President Xi Jinping inspected Meishan City, China, he emphasized that the Chengdu Plain has a reputation as the ‘State of TianFu’, and that the red line of cropland must be strictly guarded and strive to create a higher level in the new era ‘Tianfu Granary’.

The center of gravity of land type is a principal index to reflect land change. Domestic and foreign scholars mainly use the displacement and trajectory of the center of gravity to analyze the spatial mobility and temporal change trend of regional elements [1,2]. The research on land use carbon emissions predominantly centers on carbon emission accounting [3,4,5], carbon emission influencing factors analysis [6,7,8,9,10], and land use low-carbon optimization [11,12,13]. Land use carbon emissions can be classified into direct carbon emissions and indirect carbon emissions. Direct carbon emissions are carbon emissions resulting from changes in land use types and changes in land management methods [14]. The accounting methods mainly include mechanism models [15,16,17], sample plot inventory methods [18], and remote sensing estimation methods [19,20]. Indirect carbon emissions are based on carbon emissions stemming from human socio-economic activities [21]. The accounting methods mainly include the measured method [22], the material method [23], and the emission coefficient method [24,25]. Concerning the main influencing factors of land use carbon emissions, cropland and building land predominantly contribute to carbon emissions. The regression model is a common method to analyze the influencing factors of cropland carbon emissions [26,27,28], and the LMDI model is used more in the analysis of building land carbon emissions [29,30,31]. The low-carbon optimization of land use is mainly to set different low-carbon development scenarios and simulate the future land use pattern [32], including early models like CA-Markov [33,34,35] model, CLUS-S [36,37] model, Flus [38,39] model, and the newer models represented by the PLUS [40,41,42] model. The early model has a good effect in simulating future land use and has been widely used, but it cannot dynamically model the patch changes in various land use types in time and space [43,44]. In contrast, the PLUS model offers enhanced accuracy in simulating land use spatial distribution, extensively applied in carbon emissions studies at regional [45], provincial [46,47], and municipal [48,49] scales across China. Nonetheless, prior studies exhibit several limitations: ① Cropland carbon emission accounting methods are too simple and seldom conducted at the county scale. ② Existing studies predominantly disregard the notable distinctions between the influencing factors of carbon emissions from cropland and building land. ③ Previous studies have mostly set future development scenarios around ecological priority or farmland protection priority when simulating future land use patterns, but lacked the development and enhancement of carbon scenarios.

The selection of research time nodes is based on the implementation of the Golden Land Project in Sichuan Province in 2006. The year 2010 is the starting year of the Chengdu Plain Urban Agglomeration Development Plan (2009–2020). In 2014, many counties in the Chengdu Plain entered the second batch of rural reform experiments in the country. In 2018, Sichuan Province issued the ‘Sichuan Rural Revitalization Strategic Plan (2018–2022)’. In 2022, when president xi jinping visited Yongfeng Village, Taihe Town, Dongpo District, and Meishan City, he emphasized that the Chengdu Plain should strive to create a higher level of ‘Tianfu Granary’ in the new era. In general, 2006, 2010, 2014, 2018, and 2022 are important nodes for the scale utilization and protection of cropland in the Chengdu Plain. These five important nodes are picked to represent the land use change trend of the Chengdu Plain in 2006–2022. In the hope of clarifying the changing trend of land use gravity center and the peak level of land use carbon in Chengdu Plain, based on multi-source data, the research investigated the changes in land use center of six land use types and three main food crops in the Chengdu Plain from 2006 to 2022, calculated carbon emissions of different land use types, and explored the impact of important influencing factors like social, economic, and resource input on the carbon emissions of cropland and the carbon emissions of building land. The study hypothesizes three scenarios: natural scenario (NS), carbon sink scenario (CSS), and carbon reduction scenario (CRS). The land use pattern and carbon emission of the Chengdu Plain in 2030 are simulated and analyzed, and the low-carbon path and low-carbon model of 33 counties in the Chengdu Plain are proposed.

2. Materials and Methods

2.1. Study Area

The Chengdu Plain is located in the central and western Sichuan Basin, China. It is located at 29°11′ N–32°26′ N north latitude and 103°1′ E–105°15′ E east longitude. It is about 380 km2 long in the north and south, and about 180 km2 wide in the east and west. It is a subtropical monsoon climate type. It is hot in summer and has less snow and ice in winter. The average annual precipitation is about 1000 mm. It has 12 major rivers such as the Minjiang River and Tuojiang River and dozens of tributaries. The main soil types include paddy soil, purple soil, and yellow soil, accounting for 44.32%, 26.19%, and 13.50% of the Chengdu Plain, respectively. The Chengdu Plain includes Chengdu City, Deyang City, Mianyang City, Meishan City, and some districts and counties in Leshan City, totaling 33 districts and counties (Figure 1), with an administrative area of 2.6242 × 104 km2.

2.2. Data Sources

The data mainly include Landsat images, MODIS MCD15A3H data, socio-economic data, phenological data, temperature and rainfall data, soil type, ODIAC data, etc. (Table 1). Utilizing the GEE cloud platform, the code is written to complete the date and cloud screening, image splicing, cloud removal, and image cutting, and the cloud-free remote sensing image of the Chengdu Plain is captured. The typical objects are selected from the six land use types as training samples (Table 2), and the land use type data of 2006, 2010, 2014, 2018, and 2022 are obtained by supervised classification. The overall accuracy of supervised classification is more than 85%, and the Kappa coefficient is more than 80%, indicating that the classification results have high accuracy and meet the research requirements. The sown area of rice, wheat, and corn in the Chengdu Plain constitutes more than 70% of the total sown area of grain crops, and these three major grain crops are extracted. Because it is difficult to directly identify and extract rice, wheat, and corn in remote sensing images, crop area information is extracted based on phenological information. The field sampling verification was carried out in 2022, and a total of 300 samples were collected from the Chengdu Plain in spring and autumn. The overall accuracy of 2022 was 80.33% and the Kappa coefficient was 70.15%, signifying improved accuracy in the extraction of rice, wheat, and corn crops.

2.3. Research Methodology

2.3.1. Center of Gravity Model

The regional center of gravity model is mainly based on the spatial position of a specific research area as the specific research object.

D = X t + 1 − X t 2 + Y t + 1 − Y t 2 1 / 2

(1)

θ = a r c t a n Y t + 1 − Y t X t + 1 − X t X t + 1 − X t ≥ 0 θ = π + a r c t a n Y t + 1 − Y t X t + 1 − X t X t + 1 − X t < 0

(2)

X t and Y t are the latitude and longitude coordinates of the center of gravity of a certain type of land use type; D and θ are the center of gravity migration distance and angle of a certain land use type in a specific range.

2.3.2. Carbon Sink Accounting

(1) Farmland carbon sink: Crop carbon sequestration refers to the process by which crops convert CO2 in the air into carbohydrates through photosynthesis. The process of fixing carbon in crops for their own growth and development is one of the important ways to achieve carbon sinks.

C S c = ∑ i = 1 n z i × δ i × d i × h i

(3)

C S c is the carbon sink of cropland; z i is the carbon absorption ratio of i -th crop (Table 3); δ i is the economic yield of i -th crop; d i is the dry ratio of i -th crop; h i is the economic coefficient of i -th crop.

Table 3 shows the carbon sequestration rates, economic factors, dry weight ratios, root crown ratios, and straw or root nitrogen ratios of nine major crops in the Chengdu Plain, which can be used to calculate the carbon sink of major crops in the Chengdu Plain.

(2) Carbon sinks of forest, grass, water, and other and unused land: Forest, grass, water, and other and unused land mainly play a role in carbon sinks. The IPCC inventory model was used to estimate the carbon sinks of the four land types.

C S t = ∑ i = 1 6 x i × c i

(4)

C S t is the total amount of carbon sinks in forest, grass, water, and other and unused land; x i is the area of i -th land type (hm2); c i is the carbon emission coefficients of i -th land type, with general reference to the carbon absorption coefficients of 0.6046, 0.0206, 0.2530, and 0.0005 t·hm−2 × a−1 for forest, grass, water, and other and unused land, respectively [50,51].

2.3.3. Accounting for Carbon Sources

Land use carbon emissions include cultivated land agricultural production, fossil fuel combustion, cement production, and natural gas combustion. The carbon emissions of cultivated land agricultural production mainly include carbon emissions from agricultural resource input, CH4 emissions from rice cultivation, and N2O and CH4 emissions from livestock and poultry breeding. In order to facilitate calculation and comparison, CO2, N2O, CH4, etc. are uniformly converted to standard C equivalents. According to the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report, the conversion C equivalent standard is that the greenhouse effect caused by 1 t N2O is equivalent to the greenhouse effect caused by 298 t CO2, and the greenhouse effect caused by 1 t CH4 is equivalent to the greenhouse effect caused by 25 t CO2. In total, 1 t CO2 contains 0.2727 t C, and 1 t N2O and 1 t CH4 contain about 81.2646 t C and 6.8175 t C, respectively.

(1) Carbon emissions from agricultural resources input: Carbon emissions from agricultural resources input mainly come from the use of chemical fertilizers, pesticides, agricultural film, diesel oil consumed by agricultural machinery, and energy consumed by tillage and irrigation. The formula is as follows:

C E c = ∑ i = 1 n φ i × β i

(5)

C E c is the carbon emission of agricultural resource investment; β i is the amount of i -th agricultural resource input; φ i is the carbon emission coefficient of i -th agricultural resource input; according to the existing studies, the carbon sink coefficients of fertilizer, pesticide, agricultural film, agricultural diesel, tillage, and irrigation are 0.8956 kg/kg [52], 4.9341 kg/kg [53], 5.18 kg/kg [53], 0.5927 kg/kg [54], 312.6 kg/hm−2 [55], and 4.75 kg/hm−2 [53].

(2) Rice carbon emissions: CH4 emissions from rice cultivation account for a relatively high proportion of CH4 emissions in China, and also have a greater impact on global CH4 emissions [56].

C E r = φ r × S × 6.8175

(6)

C E r is the carbon emission of rice (t); φ r is the methane emission factor of rice field; taking the emission factor of single-season rice recommended by the Guidelines for the Preparation of Greenhouse Gas Inventories in Sichuan Province as the standard, φ r = 156.2 (kg/hm2); S is the sowing area of rice (hm2).

(3) N2O emissions from cultivated land: N2O emissions from cultivated land include direct and indirect emissions. Direct emissions include nitrogen fertilizer (agricultural resources have been accounted for in carbon emissions), manure, and straw returning to the field. The direct emission factor is selected from the ‘Guidelines for the preparation of greenhouse gas inventories in Sichuan Province’. The recommended value is 0.0109 tN2O/tN.

C E t = N c + N j × 0.0109 + N 2 O d + N 2 O I × 81.2646

(7)

N c is livestock manure nitrogen; N j is straw returning nitrogen; N 2 O d is N2O emission caused by atmospheric nitrogen deposition; N 2 O I is N2O emission caused by runoff leaching; C E t is the N2O-to-carbon emission of cultivated land.

(4) Carbon emissions from livestock and poultry breeding: Carbon emissions from livestock and poultry breeding are mainly produced by gastrointestinal fermentation and the excreta of livestock and poultry, including N2O emissions from animal manure management, CH4 emissions from animal manure management, and CH4 emissions from the gastrointestinal fermentation of poultry.

C E y = CH 4 y × 6.8175 + N 2 O y × 81.2646

(8)

N 2 O y is livestock and poultry breeding N2O; CH 4 y is CH4 for livestock and poultry breeding; C E y is the carbon emission of livestock and poultry breeding.

2.3.4. Partial Least Squares (PLS) Regression

Combining the existing research results and the actual situation of the Chengdu Plain, the most important influencing factors of carbon emissions from cropland include population, economic development, resource investment, planting level, and planting structure factors (Table 4), and the population factors package urbanization rate (UR). Economic development factors include rural inhabitant per capita disposable income (RDI) and average agricultural output value (AAOV). Resource investment factors include energy consumption intensity (ECI), fertilizer application intensity (FAI), pesticide application intensity (PAI), and agricultural film application intensity (AFAI). Planting level factors include mechanization level (ML), irrigation rate (IR), and farmland operation scale (FOS). Planting structure includes multiple-crop index (MCI) and food crop rate (FCR).

The specific steps of PLS regression analysis are shown in the literature [57]. According to the size of Variable Importance in Projection (VIP), the explanatory importance of independent variables to dependent variables can be determined.

VIP = k ∑ h m R d y , t h w h j 2 / R d y , t h

(9)

R d y , t h = r 2 y , t h . Reflecting the precision of variation when the variable y is explained by the principal component t h , it represents the ability of the principal component t h to explain the variable y , and r y , t h is the correlation coefficient between y and t h . When VIP > 1, it is an extremely important indicator, which has very strong explanatory significance for the dependent variable; when 0.8 < VIP < 1, it is a generally important indicator, which has general explanatory significance for the dependent variable; when VIP < 0.8, it is an unimportant indicator, which has basically no explanatory significance for the dependent variable.

2.3.5. LMDI Model

The LMDI model has been widely used in related studies due to its advantages of full decomposition, no residuals, and consistency between additive and multiplicative decomposition results [58]. The LMDI additive decomposition is used in the study.

Δ C E = C E t − C E 0 = Δ C I + Δ B I + Δ E I + Δ G I + Δ P I

(10)

φ c = Δ C I Δ C , φ B = Δ B I Δ C , φ E = Δ E I Δ C , φ G = Δ G I Δ C , φ P = Δ P I Δ C

(11)

Δ C E is the amount of changes in carbon emissions from building land; C E 0 and C E t are the carbon emissions from building land at the beginning and the end, respectively; Δ C I , Δ B I , Δ E I , Δ G I , and Δ P I are the amount of changes in carbon emissions from building land due to five factors, namely, carbon emission intensity (CEI), use efficiency (UE), energy intensity (EI), economic development (ED), and population size (PS), respectively; and φ c , φ B , φ E , φ G , and φ P are the contribution rates of Δ C I , Δ B I , Δ E I , Δ G I , and Δ P I , respectively.

2.3.6. Multi-Scenario Land Use Pattern Simulation

Referring to the relevant research results [40,59], considering the situation of land use in the Chengdu Plain, 18 main driving factors were selected from the social economy and natural environment. Natural factors include elevation, slope, average annual precipitation, average annual temperature, and distance to water. Socio-economic factors include population density, per capita GDP, distance to various roads (main roads and railways), distance to airports, high-speed rail stations, government distance, POI nuclear density, and nighttime light data.

The study hypothesis NS, CSS, and CRS for the Chengdu Plain is to achieve the peak carbon target by 2030. First, under the NS, assuming that the land use of the Chengdu Plain did not take any restrictions, the land use pattern maintained a natural development trend. Second, under the premise of ensuring food security, forest, grass, and water are set as the main sources of carbon sinks, and priority is given to protecting these land types to increase regional carbon sink capacity under the CSS. Third, under the CRS, in order to ensure food security, the building land is determined as the primary source of carbon emissions, and the area growth of building land needs to be strictly controlled.

Combined with the provisions of the ‘Sichuan Provincial Land Spatial Planning (2021–2035)’ and ‘Chengdu High Standard Farmland Building Plan (2021–2030)’, the upper limit of cropland outflow area in Chengdu Plain is set to 15%, and the upper limit of building land area increase is set to 20%. According to the agricultural protection pattern of the ‘Chengdu land space master plan’, the agricultural protection area is taken as the restriction condition of land transfer. Under the CSS, the cropland area is set to decrease by 15%. The area of building land was increased by 20%, and the cropland was transferred to the area of forest, grass, and water, which was allocated according to the proportion of cropland transferred from 2006 to 2022 (Table 5). Other and unused land refer to the results of the NS. Under the CRS, the area of cropland is reduced by 10% and the area of building land is increased by 15%. The calculation methods of forest, grassland, water, and other and unused land are the same as those of the CSS.

Based on the proportion expansion of each category in the Chengdu Plain from 2006 to 2022, the domain weights of cropland, forest, grass, water, building land, and other and unused land were determined to be 0.0394, 0.2448, 0.0033, 0.0294, 0.4607, and 0.0004, respectively. In 2030, the carbon absorption coefficients of forest, grass, water, and other and unused land will be the same as before. The carbon emission coefficients of cropland and building land are based on the carbon emissions of cropland and building land per unit area from 2006 to 2022, and predicted by EXCEL trend line.

3. Results

3.1. Analysis of Gravity Center Change in Land Use Types

3.1.1. Analysis of Gravity Center Changes in Six Land Use Types

The movement direction of the center of gravity for cropland, forest, and other and unused land in the Chengdu Plain has strong continuity in 2006–2010, 2010–2014, 2014–2018, and 2018–2022, while the change in the center of gravity of grassland, water, and building land has no continuity. (Figure 2). From 2006 to 2022, the transfer area of cropland in the central and southwestern regions of the Chengdu Plain was large, resulting in a 4.23 km shift in the center of gravity of cropland to the northeast (Table 6). The area of forest showed an expansion from the Longmen Mountains to the southeast, and the forest in the Longquan Mountains and Jianyang City increased steadily, making the center of gravity of the forest move 11.12 km to the southeast. The grass and water have relatively fixed spatial distribution, and their center of gravity changes in a closed loop, moving 3.41 km and 5.46 km, respectively. Because the position of the river itself is relatively fixed, the inflow of water is concentrated near the water area, so the center of gravity of the water moves less distance. Combined with Table 6, it can be seen that the distance of the center of gravity in each stage of the water is 2014–2018 < 2018–2022 < 2006–2010 < 2010–2014, and the expansion rate of the water along the direction of the center of gravity is also 2014–2018 < 2018–2022 < 2006–2010 < 2010–2014. The urbanization speed of Deyang City and Mianyang City is faster than that of Leshan City and Meishan City, which leads to the center of gravity of building land in the Chengdu Plain moving to the northeast by 8.44 km. The northeast inflow area of other and unused land is larger than the rest area, which makes the center of gravity move 31.58 km to the northeast. Overall, from 2006 to 2022, the reduction area of cropland in the central and western directions of the Chengdu Plain is higher than that in the northeast direction. The expansion area of water, building land, and other and unused land in the northeast direction is significantly higher than that in the southwest direction, and the increase area of forest and grass in the southeast direction is higher than that in the northwest direction.

3.1.2. Analysis of Gravity Center Changes in Major Grain Crops Rice, Wheat, and Maize

The changing trend of the gravity center of rice, wheat, and maize in the Chengdu Plain is obviously different. The change in the gravity center of rice has obvious consistency in 2006–2010, 2010–2014, 2014–2018, and 2018–2022, and the gravity center of wheat and maize has irregular change (Figure 3). From 2006 to 2022, the outflow area of rice cultivation in the central and southwestern Chengdu Plain was higher than that in the northeastern region, and it was mainly converted to other crop cultivation. The center of gravity of rice moved 15.47 km to the northeast (Table 7). The wheat outflow area in the northeast of Chengdu Plain is higher than that in the southwest, and the proportion of outflow to rice and other crops is relatively high. The wheat center of gravity moves 17.77 km to the southwest. The outflow area of corn at each stage is not spatially clustered, and the proportion of outflow to rice and other crops is relatively high. The center of gravity changes in a round-trip manner, and the corn center of gravity moves 7.52 km to the northeast.

3.2. Spatio-Temporal Changes in Carbon Source and Carbon Sink in Chengdu Plain

3.2.1. Time Changes in Carbon Source and Carbon Sink in Chengdu Plain

From a temporal perspective, focusing on carbon sources, the total carbon emissions of the Chengdu Plain increased by 13.552 million tons from 2006 to 2022. The proportion of carbon emissions from building land in the total carbon emissions from 2006 to 2022 was 81.62%, 88.56%, 90.99%, 92.91%, and 94.33%, respectively, showing an increasing trend (Table 8). The carbon emissions of cropland showed a declining trajectory year by year. From 2006 to 2022, the carbon emissions of cropland decreased by 1.6948 million tons, a decrease of 44.56%. Overall, the carbon emissions in the Chengdu Plain are mainly from building land, and the proportion is still rising. Shifting the focus to carbon sink, from 2006 to 2022, the carbon sink effect of forest has been significantly improved. The carbon absorption of forest is 0.3783, 0.4587, 0.5262, 0.5440, and 0.5909 million tons, respectively, and the contribution rate to carbon sink is 14.16%, 18.18%, 23.40%, 27.46%, and 28.09%, respectively. The carbon sink of cropland showed a downward trend, and the proportion of cropland carbon sink to total carbon sink was 85.33%, 81.28%, 75.89%, 71.75%, and 71.11%, respectively, which decreased by 14.19% in 16 years. It shows that cropland is the most important place to realize carbon sink, but the carbon sink capacity is declining. The carbon sink effect of the water area was very small and fluctuated. During the 16-year period, it only increased by 0.0024 tons, an increase of about 17.02% compared with 2006.

3.2.2. Spatial Variation in Carbon Source and Carbon Sink in Chengdu Plain

Viewed from a spatial distribution perspective, the annual average change rates of carbon emissions, carbon sinks, and cropland carbon emissions have obvious aggregation. (1) In the annual average rate of change in carbon emissions, there are two rapid growth types, which are Shuangliu District and Qingbaijiang District. The average annual growth rate of Shuangliu District is the highest, which is 5.36% (Figure 4a). The carbon emissions of 18 counties are in medium-speed growth, mainly in Chengdu municipal district, Deyang municipal district, and Mianyang City. The remaining 13 counties are growing slowly, indicating that the Chengdu Plain municipal district, Deyang municipal district, and Mianyang City as pivotal areas for future carbon emission control. (2) In the annual average rate of change in carbon sinks, there are more types of changes and more obvious spatial aggregation. There are five counties in a state of rapid decline, chiefly situated in the main urban area of Chengdu (Figure 4b), with only Wenjiang District in a state of rapid decline. There are eight counties in the state of medium-speed decline, predominantly located in the primary urban area of Chengdu and Meishan City. There are 17 counties in a state of slow decline, distributed in the edge counties of Chengdu, Deyang City, and Mianyang City. The carbon sink of Guanghan City and Shizhong District shows a slow growth trend, which is worthy of attention. In general, the decline in carbon sink level has become a common trend in the 33 counties in the Chengdu Plain. In the future, the decline in carbon sink capacity in the primary urban area of Chengdu should be slowed down and the number of counties achieving carbon sink growth should be increased. (3) In the annual average change rate of Cropland carbon emissions, there are nine counties with rapid decline, which are distributed in the Chengdu municipal district (Figure 4c). The rapid decline type is mainly distributed in Chengdu. There are 12 counties with medium-speed decline, mainly distributed in Chengdu, Leshan, and Mianyang, and 6 with slow decline, mainly distributed in Deyang. Overall, the reduction rate of carbon emissions from cropland in Chengdu is greater than that in other districts and counties. It is vital to speed up the supervision of carbon emissions from cropland in Deyang City, Dongpo District, and Jiangyou City.

3.3. Analysis of the Main Influencing Factors of Cropland Carbon Emissions

Utilizing SPSS26, PLS regression analysis was conducted. Considering that the first four principal components have more than 80% explanatory power, four principal components were selected to analyze the independent variables and dependent variables, and the effect of the regression model was analyzed from the regression coefficient, VIP value, and regression model verification.

Among the PLS regression results of the 12 indicators, (1) UR, RDI, and ML are negatively correlated with carbon emissions per unit of cropland (Table 9). It is mainly because the increase in urbanization, RDI, and ML will promote the reduction in agricultural resource investment and green development, and reduce the generation of carbon emissions. (2) AAOV, ECI, PAI, FAI, AFAI, IR, FOS, MCI, and FCR are positively correlated with carbon emissions per unit of cropland, mainly because ECI, IR, PAI, FAI, and AFAI are the main modes of agricultural resource investment, which will generate a large amount of carbon emission. MCI is an important reflection of the intensity of agricultural cultivation, and the increase in MCI will bring more agricultural resource investment and consumption, and FCR is due to the fact that rice cultivation will produce a large amount of carbon emission. AAOV and average carbon emission are positively correlated, indicating that the Chengdu Plain is still in the stage of pursuing yield rather than green ecological products. 4. Discussion

The carbon emissions of cropland in the Chengdu Plain reduced to 52.45% from 2006 to 2022, which was basically the same as Lu’s [60] opinion. The effects of RDI, FOS, and FCR on carbon emissions from cropland are basically the same as those of Huang, Guo, and Niu [61,62,63]. The carbon emissions caused by economic development increased first and then decreased [64], and the economic development of some districts and counties changed from promoting carbon emissions to inhibiting carbon emissions, which basically corresponded with the study results of Yu [65]. The CRS is more conducive to the low-carbon development of land use than the NS and the CSS, which corresponds with the research results of Wu [66].

The study puts forward suggestions for low-carbon development in the Chengdu Plain with food security and dual-carbon purposes: ① The area of cropland in the Chengdu Plain is reduced by about 40%, mainly transferred to building land in the central Plain and woodland in Longmen Mountains, Longquan Mountains, and Leshan City. In the future, it is vital to enhance the protection of cropland in this area. ② In the main grain crops, the proportion of wheat sown area in the total sown area decreased by about 34%, with the largest decline. It is necessary to increase scientific research on wheat, improve wheat quality and planting income, and increase wheat planting area, prospectively. ③ In the 21 counties of the Chengdu Plain where the unrealized cultivated land was converted from carbon source to carbon sink, priority should be given to accelerating the promotion of energy-saving agricultural tools, actively promoting the use of organic fertilizers and green pesticides instead of traditional pesticides and fertilizers, and gradually improving the quality of farmland scale management. ④ Chengdu non-municipal area, Deyang City, Mianyang City, Leshan City, and Meishan City should speed up the promotion of a low-carbon energy consumption structure. ⑤ It is necessary to speed up the construction of new areas such as the Eastern New Area of the Chengdu Plain, the Chengde New Area, and the Meishan Area of the Tianfu New Area; reduce the development intensity and population density of the primary urban area of Chengdu; and ease the resources of the primary urban area. ⑥ Build a strong national integrated computing power network national hub (Chengdu–Chongqing region) node, provide technical support for economic transformation and upgrading, and promote the development of the green service industry of Chengdu and the development of industrial Internet in other districts and counties.

The research explores the nexus between the transfer of land use center and carbon emissions, simulates the land use pattern of the Chengdu Plain under three scenarios, and proposes a low-carbon path, but there are still some shortcomings that need to be further explored. Carbon emissions accounting can scale up the accuracy of accounting with more accurate image information and more quantitative statistical data. Three simulation scenarios were designed, and other scenarios need to be further simulated and improved. Using multi-period time node data to show the continuity of data changes, the data analysis is rough, and further refined analysis is needed.

5. Conclusions

Utilizing multi-source data, this research analyzed the changes in land use centers of six land use types and three major grain crops of rice, wheat, and corn in the 33 counties of the Chengdu Plain from 2006 to 2022, calculated carbon footprints, and explored the impact of important influencing factors like social, economic, and resource input on the carbon emissions of cropland and building land. The three scenarios of NS, CSS, and CRS are hypothesized to simulate and analyze the nexus between land use pattern and carbon emission in the Chengdu Plain from 2022 to 2030, and the low-carbon path and mode of the 33 counties in the Chengdu Plain are put forward.

(1)

From 2006 to 2022, the center of gravity of land use in the Chengdu Plain changed significantly, with cropland and forest land shifting to the northeast and southeast, grassland and water center changing slightly, while the center of gravity of building land and unused land shifted significantly to the northeast. The outward area of rice predominantly focused on the central and southern parts of the Plain, resulting in the shift of its central core to the northeast, while the outward area of wheat and maize was scattered, and the change in the center of gravity was not obvious.

(2)

The carbon emissions in the Chengdu Plain demonstrated a continuous upward trajectory in general, carbon emissions increased by 13.552 million tons, carbon sinks have demonstrated a diminishing trend, with a decline of 0.5679 million tons. The carbon emissions of the 33 counties are on the rise, and the carbon sinks of 31 counties are negative. The increase rate of carbon emissions in Chengdu municipal districts and Mianyang City is greater than that of other districts and counties. The primary urban area of Chengdu has witnessed a more substantial decline in carbon sinks relative to other regions. Furthermore, the reduction in cropland carbon emissions within Chengdu has surpassed the spatial variance observed across other districts and counties.

(3)

Under the NS, CSS, and CRS, the land use sector of the Chengdu Plain can fulfill the carbon peak target by 2030. Within the 33 counties in the Chengdu Plain, 11 counties are anticipated to fall short of reaching the carbon peak under the NS, while 5 counties may not achieve the target under the CSS, and 0 counties can not achieve the target under the CRS. This indicates that adopting a carbon emission reduction model will help the counties achieve the carbon peak target. At the same time, the study also proposes targeted low-carbon paths for the 33 counties in the Chengdu Plain to meet the data support in different counties.
